dc:description: In association with a late-onset, axonal, sensorimotor polyneuropathy, MED25 was first described in a Costa Rican family with an extended multi-generational, autosomal recessive pedigree (Leal et al., 2001; PMID: 11112660; Berghoff et al., 2004; PMID: 15099588; Leal et al., 2009; PMID: 19290556). Since its first description, however, no further associated CMT families have been published. Contrarily, the only reported variant has been found in a homozygous state in 4 unaffected individuals (GnomAD). Re-assessing the first and only reported family by WES, Leal et al. identified a homozygous stop mutation in PNKP, a gene that is located in the same linkage region (Leal et al., 2018; PMID: 11112660). The authors identified 5 further families carrying biallelic loss-of-function mutations in PNKP as well, pointing towards the pathogenicity of this gene over MED25. With no further strong experimental evidence supporting the gene-disease relationship between MED25 and CMT2B, we thereby classify the gene as “DISPUTED”. The likewise associated, autosomal recessive Basel-Vanagaite-Smirin-Yosef syndrome has a congenital age at onset and does not include neuropathy in its phenotypic spectrum.
curationReasonDescription: Only one CMT2B family described with one mutation, WES identified another gene in the same family.

evidence.dc:description: In 2018, identification of the homozygous stop mutation c.1549C>T; p.Gln517Ter in PNKP by WES in the same family. Variant so far overseen as the PNKP gene annotation at the time of MED25 identification included an upstream stop codon causing the variant to be mapped outside the coding sequence. Co-segregation with MED25 missense variant in all cases indicating an ancestral founder haplotype. PNKP is located within the critical linkage region on chromosome 19q13.33. It catalyzes the 5-prime phosphorylation of nucleic acids and has an associated 3-prime phosphatase activity, an important function in DNA repair. Biallelic variants in this gene were previously linked to progressive cerebellar atrophy and polyneuropathy, ataxia with oculomotor apraxia 4 (MIM 616267), or microcephaly with seizures and developmental delay (MIM 613402). Identification of five more costa rican families with an axonal CMT phenotype all carrying biallelic LOF mutations in PNKP.

evidence.rdfs:label: A5.1
evidence.phenotypeFreeText: symmetrical weakness of the plantar extensor and flexor muscles of the ankles, distal weakness in the upper extremities, distal atrophy of the plantar muscles, atrophy of the small hand muscles, absent ankle jerks, sensory deficits in a symmetrical “stocking-glove” pattern, distal hypaesthesia and hypalgesia, decreased sense of vibration and position in the lower extremities, no sural nerve biopsy performed

evidence.dc:description: A later publication (PMID: 11112660) showed that the more likely underlying gene was not MED25, but PNKP in this family (matching the linkage region)
evidence.rdfs:label: Leal family 1
evidence.phenotypeFreeText: symmetrical weakness of the plantar extensor and flexor muscles of the ankles, distal weakness in the upper extremities, distal atrophy of the plantar muscles, atrophy of the small hand muscles, absent ankle jerks, sensory deficits in a symmetrical “stocking-glove” pattern, distal hypaesthesia and hypalgesia, decreased sense of vibration and position in the lower extremities, no sural nerve biopsy performed
